attributes.action: Additional funding for the National Health Service and Social Care Services.
attributes.additional_details:
The NHS has always been an emotive subject and rumours or thoughts of privatising the health service brings out passionate debate. Successive Governments of all parties are equally to blame for under investment and in times of crisis such as with Covid-19 ,  these Service are now severely financially overwhelmed.

It is now time for Parliament to debate increasing NI & General Taxation to provide additional ring fenced funding to fully support the NHS and Welfare Services, now and in the future.
attributes.background: By raising additional funding through NI contributions & General Taxation. All additional funding to be protected by law and “Ring Fenced” for the purpose of ensuring adequate financial resources for the National Health and Social Care Services.

You may wish to sign some of these petitions:

Ensure continued Universal health cover by legally committing to a minimum spend: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300925

Create a National Health Insurance Tax for the NHS: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/313361

Raise the rate of income tax and corporation tax to fund the NHS: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/313995

We would like the government to consider social care as equally important to NHS: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/302897

Revoke the Health and Social Care Act 2012 and renationalise the NHS: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/300019

You can find out more about coronavirus and how you can protect yourself and others here:

www.gov.uk/coronavirus
https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/

The Government has also created an online service to help you out what you can do if you’re struggling because of coronavirus: https://www.gov.uk/find-coronavirus-support

You may also be interested to know that because of the large number of petitions that have been started in relation to coronavirus, the Petitions Committee has been questioning the Government about its response to the coronavirus outbreak.
